puppyTrainingCourses.title: Potty Training
puppyTrainingCourses.description: Teach your puppy where and when to go to the bathroom using a consistent routine and positive reinforcement.

puppyTrainingCourses.title: Potty Training
puppyTrainingCourses.description: Teach your puppy where and when to go to the bathroom using a consistent routine and positive reinforcement.

lessonPart.title: Introduction to Potty Training

lessonInfo.title: Explanation:
lessonInfo.text: In this lesson, you’ll introduce your dog to a designated potty area. Consistency is key for building a routine and making sure your dog associates this spot with doing its business.

list.step: Choose a potty area outside, ideally a spot away from where the dog plays.
Bring your dog to the potty area immediately after meals, naps, or play sessions.
Use a command like 'Go Potty' every time you take them there.
Wait patiently and avoid distractions.
Praise and reward them with a treat when they go potty in the right spot.

lessonPart.tip: Bring a toy or chew to the potty spot so your dog feels relaxed. This can help speed up the process.
lessonPart.warning: Avoid changing the potty spot too soon, as this can confuse your dog and slow down their progress.

lessonPart.title: Establishing a Routine

lessonInfo.title: Explanation:
lessonInfo.text: Dogs thrive on routine, so one of the most effective methods to begin potty training is to establish a specific spot where your dog can go. This reinforces consistency and teaches them that there’s a designated area for relieving themselves.

list.step: Create a schedule that includes taking your dog out first thing in the morning, after meals, after naps, and before bedtime.
Stick to the same potty command (e.g., 'Go Potty').
Gradually extend the time between potty breaks as your dog starts to understand the routine.
Always praise your dog after successful potty trips to reinforce the behavior.

lessonPart.tip: Bring a toy or chew to the potty spot so your dog feels relaxed. This can help speed up the process.
lessonPart.warning: Avoid changing the potty spot too soon, as this can confuse your dog and slow down their progress.

lessonPart.title: Crate Training to Aid Potty Training

lessonInfo.title: Explanation:
lessonInfo.text: Crate training can be a great tool for potty training. Dogs naturally avoid soiling their sleeping area, which helps teach them bladder control.

list.step: Select a crate that is large enough for your dog to stand up, turn around, and lie down in comfortably.
Introduce the crate as a safe, positive space by placing a bed or blanket inside and offering treats.
Gradually increase the time your dog spends in the crate while supervising.
Take your dog out to the potty area immediately after letting them out of the crate.
Reward with praise and treats when they go potty in the right spot.

lessonPart.tip: Bring a toy or chew to the potty spot so your dog feels relaxed. This can help speed up the process.
lessonPart.warning: Avoid changing the potty spot too soon, as this can confuse your dog and slow down their progress.

lessonPart.title: Handling Indoor Accidents

lessonInfo.title: Explanation:
lessonInfo.text: Accidents happen, especially in the early stages of potty training. How you handle these accidents can either help or hinder the training process.

list.step: If you catch your dog in the act, calmly interrupt them by clapping or saying 'no.'
Immediately take your dog outside to their potty area.
If they finish going potty outside, reward them with praise and a treat.
Clean up any accidents indoors with an enzyme-based cleaner to remove all scent, as leftover smells may encourage repeat accidents.

lessonPart.tip: Bring a toy or chew to the potty spot so your dog feels relaxed. This can help speed up the process.
lessonPart.warning: Avoid changing the potty spot too soon, as this can confuse your dog and slow down their progress.
